newsitem.title: USA: BankBoston seen finding new buyer for unit.
newsitem.headline: BankBoston seen finding new buyer for unit.

text.p: NEW YORK, Jan 30 (Reuter) BankBoston Corp, which pulled the plug Thursday on its deal to sell a consumer finance unit to Mercury Finance Co for $458 million in Mercury stock, will probably have little trouble finding another buyer for the unit, analysts said.

"At the time they (BankBoston) were structuring this deal there were four or five other firms that expressed interest or made bids on Fidelity (Acceptance Corp)," said analyst Nancy Bush of Brown Brothers Harriman. "I don't think they're going to get the kind of sweetheart deal they got with Mercury," Bush said.

BankBoston acted to terminate the deal with Mercury a little more than 24 hours after Mercury announced it was restating four years of earnings results because of the discovery of accounting irregularities.

Mercury's stock has not traded on the New York Stock Exchange Wednesday or Thursday although there were trades in Europe at $4.25 a share. Mercury had closed in the U.S. at a price of $14.875 a share Tuesday.
"Timing is everything," Bush observed regarding BankBoston's close call. A clause in the agreement about materially adverse developments allowed BankBoston to get out of the deal.

"Given what seems to be an increasingly clouded picture and fingerpointing I guess the indication was 'let's get out of that and look elsewhere,'" said analyst Frank Barkocky of Josepthal Lyon & Ross.
Barkocy said BankBoston would probably go back to the Fidelity suitors it talked to before.

Bush noted that BankBoston said last year that it was examining all of its national consumer busineses. Fidelity Acceptance was the largest piece. Another unit which is a candidate for sale is one specializing in the finance of recreational vehicles.

Barkocy had written in a research report early Thursday before the termination announcement that other than surprise and disappointment, and a delay in its strategy, the Mercury situation had no material effect on BankBoston.
BankBoston, whose stock had slipped 1/4 on Wednesday, rose 1-1/4 to 70-1/2 Thursday.
